title-group.article-title: The Duality of Clusters and Statistical Interactions

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: David Melamed is an assistant professor of sociology at the University of South Carolina. His research interests are in mathematical sociology, social network analysis, social psychology, status organizing processes, and stratification. He received his PhD from the University of Arizona in 2012. Some of his published work has appeared in the American Sociological Review, Lecture Notes in Computer Science, Social Psychology Quarterly, and Social Science Research.

Ronald L. Breiger is a professor in the Department of Sociology, and an affiliated faculty member of the Graduate Interdisciplinary Program in Statistics and of the School of Government and Public Policy, at the University of Arizona. His interests include social networks, adversarial networks, stratification, mathematical models, theory, and measurement issues in cultural and institutional analysis. In the past two years, he has published in Lecture Notes in Computer Science, Poetics, the Annual Review of Sociology, and other venues.

Eric Schoon is a doctoral candidate in sociology at the University of Arizona and a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow. His interests include social networks, adversarial networks, social theory, and the application of relational methodology to the study of culture. He has published in Lecture Notes in Computer Science and Contexts.

abstract.p: We contend that clusters of cases co-constitute statistical interactions among variables. Interactions among variables imply clusters of cases within which statistical effects differ. Regression coefficients may be productively viewed as sums across clusters of cases, and in this sense regression coefficients may be said to be “composed” of clusters of cases. We explicate a four-step procedure that discovers interaction effects based on clusters of cases in the data matrix, hence aiding in inductive model specification. We illustrate with two examples. One is a reanalysis of data from a published study of the effect of social welfare policy extensiveness on poverty rates across 15 countries. The second uses General Social Survey data to predict four different dimensions of ego-network homophily. We find support for our contention that clusters of the rows of a data matrix may be exploited to discover statistical interactions among variables that improve model fit.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: We contend that clusters of cases co-constitute statistical interactions among variables. Conventional quantitative analysis in sociology presumes that the rows of a data matrix are related to an outcome by a series of estimated coefficients. Beyond this boilerplate of modeling, we argue that the relations among the cases co-constitute the relations among the variables, creating a duality (Breiger 1974, 2009; Martin 2006) between clusters of cases and statistical interactions among variables. Interactions among variables may be productively understood as clusters of cases such that each cluster exhibits distinctive statistical effects.

We demonstrate the duality of clusters and interactions by a four-step inductive process to discover and describe statistical interactions. First, we perform a cluster analysis on the rows (cases) of a data matrix. Second, after we identify a parsimonious cluster-analytic solution, we adjoin cluster identification, as a series of dummy variables, to a regression model that includes the original covariates. Third, provided that cluster identification is significant, we identify the relevant interaction effect, or other nonlinearity, by means of a novel technique for examining each cluster’s contribution to the estimated regression coefficients. Finally, we include any interaction effects discovered by the above process by adding corresponding terms in the regression model. If cluster identification is significant, net of the original covariates, then there is a nonlinearity in the data since the clusters are based on the original covariates and their effects are controlled as linear additive effects in the model.1 To the extent that the nonlinearity is a statistical interaction, then the clusters of cases and the statistical interactions are detecting the same pattern in the data.

To illustrate how clusters of cases and statistical interactions create a duality, we work through two examples in some detail. The first comes from a series of published regression models on the relationship between post-tax poverty rates and various country-level covariates for 15 Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries (Kenworthy 1999). The second example uses a single matrix of independent variables to explain four dimensions of homophily employing data from the 2004 General Social Survey (GSS; Davis and Smith 1972–2006). In both examples, we show how clusters of cases co-constitute statistical interactions among variables.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: For simplicity and straightforwardness, our presentation focuses on ordinary least squares (OLS) regression. In OLS regression, a series of independent variables, plus a constant term when the variables are not centered, are used to predict a continuous outcome. The run-of-the-mill multiple regression equation implies equation (1), where yˆ is a vector of predicted values on the outcome, X is a matrix of independent variables, plus a constant term, and b is a vector of estimated coefficients. An alternative to equation (1) can be inferred based on the singular value decomposition (SVD) of X. Let n be the numbers of rows and p be the number of columns in X. Then the SVD of X, given in equation (2), generates an n × p matrix of orthogonal row scores (U), a p × p matrix of orthogonal column scores (V), and a p × p diagonal matrix of weights (S). In equation (2), VT is notation for the transpose of matrix V. Belsley, Kuh, and Welsch (2004) provide an introduction to the SVD decomposition. Equation (3) presents an SVD alternative to equation (1). The matrix UUT is known widely as the hat matrix that is so vital to regression diagnostics (Belsley et al. 2004), and it also represents a network of profile similarity among the cases (see the application in Breiger et al. 2011).1yˆ=Xb.2X=USVT.3yˆ=UUTy.

In OLS regression, the best linear solution to the vector of coefficients is given in equation (4). The SVD analog to the formula for the regression coefficients (obtained by substitution of [2] into [4]) is given in equation (5), which we make use of below.4b=(XTX)−1XTy.5b=VS−1UTy.

The U matrix from the SVD of X represents the orthogonalized row space of the independent variable matrix. For our purposes, we prefer to cluster on the U matrix rather than the original data matrix X. Clustering on U is more effective than clustering on X because the data have been clarified through the orthogonalization process (Skillicorn 2006:371; Van de Geer 1971:256-57).2 We use k-means clustering on the U matrix. K-means completely partitions the cases into a prespecified number of clusters such that the distance between each case and its corresponding cluster mean is minimized. For each data point, k-means allocates that point to each cluster on a trial basis, computes the movement of the cluster mean after adding that point, and places data points into clusters based on minimizing the movement of each cluster’s mean, repeating this process until convergence. (Everitt and Hothorn [2006] provide an introduction to k-means clustering.) We use a very high number (10,000) of starting points (i.e., cluster means) and iterations to assure that the algorithm finds an optimal solution.3 To identify a parsimonious clustering of the data, we estimate nine k-means cluster analyses, representing solutions with 2 through 10 clusters. As recommended by Everitt and Hothorn (2006:251), for each clustering we compute the sums of squared errors made in placing each case into its respective cluster and then plot the sums of squares by the number of clusters. The resulting figure resembles a scree plot in its appearance and interpretation.

Once a parsimonious clustering solution is obtained, we include cluster membership as a series of dummy variables appended to the original X matrix in an OLS regression model. We interpret the significance of cluster identification to indicate nonlinearities in the effects of the original covariates on the outcome, since the original covariates are already included as linear additive effects in the model.

To identify the relevant nonlinearity with respect to the covariates, we examine each cluster’s aggregate contribution to the estimated regression coefficients. Equation (5) shows the matrix solution (using terms from the SVD) to the first step in identifying each of the cluster’s contributions, but rather than multiply the matrix VS−1UT by y, we multiply each row of VS−1UT by y.4 The resulting matrix is of size p × n. We then sum the columns of this matrix according to cluster identification. The resulting matrix is p × k, where k refers to the number of clusters. Summing across the columns (clusters) of this matrix yields the estimated regression coefficients when the outcome is regressed on X (Breiger, Melamed, and Schoon 2010). These are the same regression coefficients as in the usual model (see equations [1], [4], and [5] above). The innovation here, however, is the ability to decompose each regression coefficient as a sum across the clusters of cases that have been identified. In this sense, regression coefficients may be said to be “composed” of the effects of the clusters of cases.

The procedure detailed in the previous paragraph allows us to examine how the estimated effects of the independent variables vary by cluster membership and offers an opportunity to identify the relevant nonlinearity. Based on how the coefficients vary by cluster, we obtain an interaction term and include it in the regression model.5 This constitutes the duality: If cluster membership is significant when included as a series of dummy variables, then this information may be used to discover an interaction among variables. This relationship, however, is conditional on the presence of nonlinearities in the data as well as on model specification. If cluster identification is not significant, then the interaction effects are also going to be nonsignificant.6

sec.title: Example 1: Poverty Rates in 15 Countries
sec.p: We now turn to the first of our two examples. In an influential publication, Kenworthy (1999) uses data from 15 countries to study poverty rates in absolute terms (absolute referring to the proportion of people in a nation with incomes below a specified level that is held constant across countries). The predictor variables are social welfare policy extensiveness, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, and each country’s poverty rate prior to the application of taxation and income-transfer policies. Kenworthy uses three indicators of social welfare policy extensiveness (government transfers, decommodification, and the social wage)7 in three different OLS regression models. We use these same three regression models (see Kenworthy 1999:1131, table 4) as our first set of examples to illustrate the duality of clusters and statistical interactions.

We computed the SVD of each of the three matrices of independent variables (one for each of the three regression models Kenworthy estimated). We then clustered on the U matrices as described above. Figure 1 presents the total sum of squared errors made in placing each case into its respective cluster by the number of clusters. As outlined above, we estimated 9 cluster analytic solutions corresponding to 2 through 10 clusters. As illustrated in Figure 1, a four-cluster solution appears to yield a reasonable trade-off between model fit (i.e., smaller sums of squares) and parsimony (fewer clusters). In fact, a four-cluster solution was discovered for each of the first two matrices and a three-cluster solution was discovered for the third. Next, we included cluster identification in Kenworthy’s original regression models in a step-wise approach including one dummy variable at a time. This procedure compares each cluster to all of the others and uses fewer degrees of freedom than including all but one dummy variable. The results indicate that cluster membership has rather low p values for Kenwothy’s first two models, but not for the third.8 This indicates that the clusters are picking up on some nonlinearity in the data with respect to the first two regression models, since the linear effects of the variables that contribute to the clusters are included as covariates.

caption.p: Plot of sums of squared errors by the number of clusters in each solution.

sec.p: The next step is to identify the relevant interaction effect for models 1 and 2. To do so, we computed each cluster’s contribution to the estimated standardized regression coefficients. Table 1 presents these results. In Table 1, cluster 1’s contribution to the coefficient for GDP per capita is −.351, cluster 2’s contribution is −.024, cluster 3’s contribution is −.035, and cluster 4’s contribution is .228. Notice that these values sum to the estimated standardized regression coefficient (−.182) that Kenworthy (1999) reports. The same result (the usual regression coefficient as a summation across clusters of cases) is true as well for each of the other coefficients in Kenworthy’s models. Figure 2 plots the clusters’ contributions to the estimated regression coefficients for model 1. Based on this figure, it appears that a pretax poverty by government transfers interaction may be present. Specifically, notice that in cluster 1 the effects of pretax poverty and government transfers are largely differentiated. Then in clusters 2 and 3, they become similar in their effects on posttax poverty rates. Finally, in cluster 4, the effects become differentiated again. Moreover, Figure 3 presents each cluster’s contribution to the estimated standardized regression coefficients for model 2. We see the exact same pattern as we did with model 1. Based on this information, we conclude that the relevant nonlinearity for model 1 is the government transfers by pretax poverty interaction (Figure 2) and that the relevant nonlinearity for model 2 is the decommodification by pretax poverty interaction (Figure 3).

In the table above, we are decomposing each coefficient by cluster. Summing across the four clusters in each row yields the estimated regression coefficient in Kenworthy’s (1999: table 4) regression model, except for minor rounding error.

sec.p: To check whether the interaction effect, as identified above, is the relevant nonlinearity, we added the interaction terms to Kenworthy’s (1999) original regression equations. Table 2 presents the results of the original equations (models 1 and 3) and the models with the interaction terms included (models 2 and 4). In model 2, the government transfers by pretax poverty rate interaction is indeed significant and it explains an additional 8 percent of the variation in posttax poverty rates. In model 4, the decommodification by pretax poverty rate interaction is also significant and it explains an additional 10 percent of the variation in posttax poverty rates. These results support our contention that clusters of cases co-constitute interactions among variables. Furthermore, for Kenworthy’s model 3, the model in which cluster identification was nonsignificant, we included each of the three potential interaction effects and found no significant results; again, this supports the assertion that there is a duality between clusters and interactions: where cluster membership is (non)significant, there is (not) a corresponding interaction effect or other nonlinearity present in the data.

sec.p: In this example, each of the independent variable matrices up to this point has been different. Our next example illustrates the duality of clusters of cases and interactions of variables using a single independent variable matrix to predict each of four different outcomes. In the following text, we describe our measures and outcomes for a second example, using data from the GSS. Again the results are consistent with our contention.

sec.title: Example 2: Predicting Homophily
sec.p: Our second example comes from the 2004 wave of the GSS (Davis and Smith 1972–2006). We employ nine sociologically relevant variables to separately predict four distinct dimensions of ego-network homophily. The independent variables are race, education, sex, income, size of place, marital status, number of children, age, and age2. Table 3 presents the means and standard deviations for these variables. Race is a dummy variable that compares whites to all others. Education is measured in years. Income and size of place are measured on ordered categories but are treated as continuous in our regression models.9 Marital status compares married individuals to all others. Number of children is a count, and age is continuous.

caption.p: Means and (Standard Deviations) for the GSS Variables.

fn.p: Note: GSS = general social survey.

sec.p: The GSS asked respondents with whom they discussed important matters. For each of up to five alters, respondents were asked several questions about these alters. They were asked about the age, education, race, and sex of their discussion partners, among other things. Based on this information, we generated four homophily variables that measure how homophilous the respondents’ ego networks are on age, education, race, and sex. Homophily refers to the principle that a “contact between similar people occurs at a higher rate than among dissimilar people” (McPherson, Smith-Lovin, and Cook 2001:416). The race and sex homophily variables represent the proportion of the respondent’s ego-network that is of the same race and sex as the respondent. The education of alters was measured on a five category ordinal scale. We coded the respondent and his or her alters as being homophilous if the respondent’s educational attainment, in years, was in the alter’s category or in one of the adjacent categories.10 The final variable is a continuous measure of ego-network age homophily. The ages of alters were measured continuously. For each respondent/alter pair, we coded them as a “1” if they were the same age or separated by only one year. If they were separated by more than one year, then we inverted the absolute distance between them so that as they became more separated on age (i.e., less homophilous), the value assigned to them approached zero. To be consistent with our other measures of homophily, we scaled this variable to have a range from zero to one. In this way, we illustrate the relevance for improved model fit of our method for discovering interactions on the basis of the clustering of cases.11

As described above, we have one matrix of independent variables with 596 cases exhibiting no missing data and four dependent variables.12 This enables us to illustrate our procedure on four different models, except that here, unlike with the Kenworthy data, the independent variable matrix is the same across our models. The first step in our procedure is to cluster on the cases. We computed the SVD of the X matrix, plus a constant term, and clustered on the corresponding orthogonalized row-space matrix, U. We computed nine cluster analyses corresponding to 2 through 10 clusters, computed the sums of squared errors, and plotted the sums of squares by the number of clusters. Once again, a four-cluster solution yielded a reasonable trade-off between parsimony and model fit. We included cluster identification as a series of three dummy variables with the original nine covariates. The results of these regression models are presented in Table 4. The results of the regressions suggest that cluster membership is highly significant for age and race and that one of the contrasts in the sex homophily model is significant. There is no cluster effect for the education homophily model.

Our next step is to identify the relevant nonlinearity. We computed each cluster’s contribution to the estimated regression coefficients as above. The results for the race homophily model are reported in Table 5.13 Notice again that each regression coefficient is a sum across clusters. Aside from the constant term, most of the variability in the clusters’ contributions to the coefficients occurs with race and sex. As it happens, the k-means clustering procedure produced a cluster of all women (cluster 2) and a cluster of all men (cluster 3). Because there is no variability on sex in these clusters, the actual effects only play out in the constant term. The effects of race do vary by cluster in a meaningful way, however. The next largest coefficient for this model is for income, and the effects of income vary by cluster. All of the other variables have relatively small effects that are stable across the clusters. Based on this information, we conclude that the relevant nonlinearity is a race by income interaction effect.

sec.p: Table 6 presents the regressions of the four dimensions of homophily on the interaction of income and race, along with all the original covariates. Where cluster identification was highly significant (the age and race models), the interaction effect is statistically significant at conventional levels (i.e., p < .05). For the sex homophily model, where only one of the contrasts was significant, the interaction effect is significant at the p < .10 level. These findings are also consistent with our general claim that clusters of cases co-constitute statistical interactions. In this example, we were able to demonstrate that when cluster identification is highly significant, then the identified interaction effect is also significant. At the same time, we demonstrated that when cluster identification is marginally significant, as in the sex homophily model, then the relevant interaction effect is also marginally significant.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: The approach introduced here for discovering nonlinearities in regression analysis has implications for the development of both substantive and theoretical knowledge. As demonstrated through the two examples above, this approach allows for the identification of interaction effects that may not otherwise be indicated by theory or extant substantive knowledge. Among the most direct benefits of this approach is its potential application to data sets that might lack the statistical power necessary for other methods of inductive model specification, such as stepwise deletion procedures. Leveraging the duality outlined in this article might allow analysts to unearth meaningful interactions, particularly in instances where data are limited or available samples are small.

What is more, if interactions between more than two variables are anticipated or desired, then we suggest using our procedure to identify a two-way interaction effect, and then reestimating the procedure including the interaction term with the original covariates. If the effect of the interaction varies with another variable in the model, as indicated by step 3 of our procedure, then this is suggestive of a three-way interaction effect. There is no reason to believe that higher order interactions could not be discerned in a similar manner using our procedure.

A related point has to do with computing multiple tests of significance. When several statistical tests are estimated, best practice suggests that a correction is required to obtain appropriate p values (e.g., Neter et al. 1996:725-38). Step-wise interaction detection procedures, for example, might estimate every two-way interaction effect, and each one increases the likelihood of making a Type I error. Our procedure, on the other hand, eliminates the need to estimate several interaction effects, which thereby reduces the likelihood of a Type I error in a principled way. This is because the clusters are based on the row space of the X matrix, not the X matrix with respect to y (as in a step-wise procedure).

While the examples used to illustrate our technique draw on areas of study that enjoy well-established bases of cumulative theoretical and substantive knowledge, there are many areas of interest to both social scientists and policy makers that have not been subject to such extensive development. These areas range from the short-term effects of new domestic policies to insurgencies or rare events such as the housing market crash and the global recession. Particularly for those areas that require new theoretical and substantive development, the ability to improve the efficiency of inductive model specification could in many cases be quite important.

Looking at the other side of this coin, the approach introduced here allows for more rigorous theory testing through an efficient interrogation of scope conditions, or conditions that must hold for the theory to be applicable (Walker and Cohen 1985). Analysts may erroneously conclude that the empirical evidence supports a social theory when in reality the relationship is only present in some of the cases. This is particularly relevant in light of the relative ease with which social scientists can obtain large databases that yield small standard errors. If net effects are found to vary by cluster, as in our second example, the theoretical inference is not as strong as when one only considers a single main effect term. Usual research practice is (in effect) to consider the entire data set comprising of a single cluster. This practice results in model misspecification whenever clustering of cases implies additional interactions among variables. The ideas developed in this article can be extended to more complex models, and we have considered them in the context of logistic regression models (Melamed et al. 2012).

Related to the above issue of identifying scope conditions, examining the aggregate effects of regression coefficients within clusters of cases is a desirable practice for evaluating the robustness of theoretical claims. If net effects of predictors on an outcome variable are consistent across the identified clusters, then that is a more rigorous validation of a theory than merely showing that a single main effect is significant for the full data file. That is, our procedure can help answer the following question: Is the proposed theoretical process robust across all of the points in the sample space? This question is different than the traditional quantitative approach of identifying an average effect that applies to the entirety of the sample space.

Coupled with the ability to more rigorously test theory and identify scope conditions, our clustering procedure allows us to examine the combinatorial effects of causal factors. Approaches to configurational analysis (Rihoux and Ragin 2008)—as exemplified by Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA; e.g., Byrne and Ragin 2009; Ragin 2008; see also Schaefer 2010 for the case of homophily studies)—demonstrate how multiple conjunctions of causal conditions can lead to a given outcome. One of the great benefits of QCA is the presumption of multifinality, which is the idea that a single factor might have different effects depending on what it is combined with. Conceptually, this is very similar to the idea of an interaction term. However, Grofman and Schneider (2009) note that, while drawing comparisons between the causal configurations produced by QCA and statistical interactions may seem appropriate, a fundamental difference between the two lies in the fact that configurational analysis aims to find the best fit for the greatest number of cases, whereas interactions are calculated using net effects. We assert that the approach outlined in this article helps bridge the gap between these two approaches, evaluating the presence of interactions by retaining the comparative element across clusters (which in turn retains the goal of finding the best fit for a subset of cases) while simultaneously allowing for the improvement of the net effects model.

In summary, we demonstrated how clusters of cases co-constitute statistical interactions by outlining a method wherein clusters derived from the row space matrix of the SVD of a data matrix are used to reveal the presence of interactions within a linear regression model. We provided the theoretical and methodological background to the approach and subsequently applied it in two examples. In each case, the clusters indicate significant interactions. This, we argue, supports the claim of co-constitution and, in turn, the duality of clusters and statistical interactions.

Following Skillicorn (2006:371) and Van de Geer (1971:256-57), we say that the data in X have been “clarified” in U, which provides an orthogonalized representation of the row space of X. Geometric representation of each row of X is usually given by the Mahalanobis distance of this vector from the origin (and, indeed, a conventional interpretation of diagonal cells of the hat matrix emphasizes the Mahalanobis distance of each row of X from the origin). However, we note that diagonal cells of UUT (which is identical to the hat matrix; equation [3]) give the Euclidean distance of the corresponding row of U from the origin. K-means clustering seems particularly well-suited for our purposes when applied to the orthogonalized matrix U.

Social wage refers to the percentage of former income that a median-income earner would receive if he or she stopped working.

Our approach takes the individual respondent as the unit of analysis focusing on aspects of the respondent’s ego-network (see Marsden 1987; Moore 1990 for similar approaches). Other recent analyses of homophily are based on dyads or the wider network as units of analysis. Schaefer (2010) applied lattice analysis to the earlier (1985) GSS networks module to show how certain dimensions of homophily do and do not coincide. Wimmer and Lewis (2010) have recently modeled tie formation among an entire cohort of college students. The former focuses on dyads as the unit of analysis and the latter focuses on the formation of relationships among the nodes in the cohort embedded within the larger network structure.

We used list-wise deletion of cases with missing data. In general, our procedure requires complete cases. If procedures such as multiple imputation (e.g., Allison 2002) are used to account for missing data, we suggest sensitivity analyses on identified interactions to ensure that they are consistent across versions of the data.

The results for the age and sex homophily models are almost identical to the results for the race homophily model. Each cluster’s contribution to the estimated coefficients for these models is available upon request from the first-listed author.
